title: Determine if Pencil Lead is Ohmic

content.question:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are to experimentally determine if a length of pencil lead is an ohmic conductor at room temperature. Their setup includes a battery of voltage <math alttext="script uppercase E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, several resistors that each have of resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the pencil lead with length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and connecting wires. The students are not expected to break the pencil lead. The students are expected to determine if the pencil lead is ohmic by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to an ammeter and a voltmeter as well as other equipment typically found in a high school physics lab but must use a setup similar to the one shown above.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

frqParts.text:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are to experimentally determine if a length of pencil lead is an ohmic conductor at room temperature. Their setup includes a battery of voltage <math alttext="script uppercase E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>ε</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, several resistors that each have of resistance <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the pencil lead with length <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and connecting wires. The students are not expected to break the pencil lead. The students are expected to determine if the pencil lead is ohmic by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to an ammeter and a voltmeter as well as other equipment typically found in a high school physics lab but must use a setup similar to the one shown above.

(a) Clearly identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure to be used to determine if the lead is ohmic. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.
(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the horizontal and vertical axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine if the lead is ohmic?
(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine if the pencil lead is an ohmic conductor.

(e) After completing their calculations, the students find that their pencil lead fit the model of an ohmic resistor, but other lab groups determined that the lead was nonohmic. Explain what experimental factor could explain this difference and justify your answer.

skill.text: 3.A: Create experimental procedures that are appropriate for a given scientific question.
